abstract.text: A set of methods that provides accessibility information about views and controls in an app’s user interface.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: informal protocol provides accessibility information about an app’s user interface elements. Assistive apps, such as VoiceOver, convey this information to users with disabilities to help them use the app.
Standard UIKit controls and views implement the
methods and are accessible to assistive apps by default. This means that if your app uses only standard controls and views, such as

, you need only supply app-specific details when the default values are incomplete. You can do this by setting these values in Interface Builder or by setting the properties in this informal protocol.
class, which represents custom user interface objects, also implements the
informal protocol. If you create a completely custom
subclass, you might need to create an instance of
to represent it. In this case, you’d support all the
properties to correctly set and return the accessibility element’s properties.

abstract.text: Make your apps accessible to everyone who uses Apple devices.
Provide a set of methods that view subclasses use to make subcomponents accessible as separate elements.
The deepest descendant of the accessibility hierarchy that has the focus.
Returns the deepest descendant of the accessibility hierarchy that contains the specified point.
A Boolean value that indicates whether to hide the accessibility elements.
A Boolean value that indicates whether VoiceOver ignores the accessibility elements within views that are siblings of the element.
A localized string that contains a brief description of the result of performing an action on the accessibility element.
The frame of the accessibility element in screen coordinates.
A localized string that contains the value of the accessibility element.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the element is an accessibility element that an assistive app can access.
A Boolean value that indicates whether VoiceOver groups the accessibility elements that are children of the element, regardless of their positions on the screen.
The path of the element in screen coordinates.
The activation point for the accessibility element in screen coordinates.
A succinct label in a localized string that identifies the accessibility element.
The language to use when speaking the accessibility element's label, value, and hint.
The navigation style to apply to the object and its elements.
The combination of accessibility traits that best characterizes the accessibility element.
An array of elements that serves as the headers for the accessibility element.
An array of custom rotors for the current accessibility element.
The underlying attributed version of the accessibility hint.
The underlying attributed version of the accessibility label.
The underlying attributed version of the accessibility value.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the accessibility element performs an action due to user interaction.
A named context that helps identify and classify the type of text inside an element.
The underlying attributed versions of the accessibility user input labels.
An array of localized labels the user provides to refer to the accessibility element.
A value that configures how VoiceOver produces audio for direct touch areas.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A namespace for accessibility symbols for UIKit apps.
Constants that configure how VoiceOver produces audio for direct touch areas.
An accessibility notification that an app can send.
The types of system Zoom that can be in effect.
Posts a notification to assistive apps.
Notifies the system when the app’s focus changes to a new location.
An element that should be accessible to users with disabilities, but that isn’t accessible by default.
Constants that describe how to navigate an object’s elements with an assistive app.
Constants that describe how an accessibility element behaves.
A control that executes your custom code in response to user interactions.
The AssistiveTouch accessibility feature.
A horizontal control that consists of multiple segments, each segment functioning as a discrete button.
A view that presents data using rows in a single column.
Make your UIKit apps accessible to everyone who uses iOS and tvOS.
Handle notifications with keys in the user info dictionary.
The names of notifications that the accessibility system generates.
Apply attributes to text in an attributed string to modify the pronunciation of that text.
Add VoiceOver support to make your iOS app more accessible to users who are blind or have low vision.
Apply attributes to text in an attributed string to convey extra information about the text.
Provide a set of methods that view subclasses use to make subcomponents accessible as separate elements.
